question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
If $10^{51} - 9$ is written as an integer in standard form, what is the sum of the integer's digits?
inference:
$10^{51} - 9 = 1\underbrace{00\dots 0}_{51 \text{ zeros}} - 9 = 1\underbrace{00\dots 0}_{50 \text{ zeros}} 1 \times 10^{50} - 9 = \underbrace{999\dots9}_{50 \text{ nines}} 1$

The number is $99...91$ with 50 nines.
The sum of the digits is $50 \times 9 + 1 = 450 + 1 = 451$
Final Answer: $\boxed{451}$
ground_truth: Since $10^{51}$ is the least integer with $52$ digits, $10^{51}-9$ has 51 digits.  The ones digit is 1 and all the other digits are 9.  The sum of the digits is $9\cdot 50 + 1=\boxed{451}$.

inference:
The number is $10^{51} - 9$.  This is equal to $100...00$ (51 zeros) - 9.  This can be written as $99...91$ (50 nines).
The sum of the digits is $50 \times 9 + 1 = 450 + 1 = 451$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{451}$
ground_truth: Since $10^{51}$ is the least integer with $52$ digits, $10^{51}-9$ has 51 digits.  The ones digit is 1 and all the other digits are 9.  The sum of the digits is $9\cdot 50 + 1=\boxed{451}$.
